intro: Lupinus sellulus, commonly known as the narrowleaf lupine, is a perennial flowering plant native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its upright growth habit and clusters of pea-like flowers. The plant has compound leaves with numerous small leaflets and produces pods that contain several seeds. Lupinus sellulus is adapted to grow in well-drained soils and is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. It plays an important role in nitrogen fixation, improving soil fertility in its ecosystem.
